data.title: Test: Using basename for terminal title
data.body:
Covers https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/30152
- [x] Windows @rebornix 
- [x] Linux @roblourens 
- [x] Mac @ramya-rao-a 

Complexity: 1
- We are now using basename to trim terminal titles, verify that various process titles are as expected (ie: when `$SHELL=/bin/bash` -> `bash`)
- In Windows we strip the `.exe` from the title (`powershell.exe -> powershell`)
- Verify that the terminal does not flicker to undefined or blank when creating a terminal

data.title: Support conditional activation events
data.body:
It would be useful for a heavyweight extension to be provide configuration options for when it is activated. 

This has come up in https://github.com/Dart-Code/Dart-Code/pull/399 . The Dart-Code's extension is primarily for .dart files, but there are configuration options that enable functionality for .html files. We're hesitant to activate the extension for all html files, unless that configuration option is set, since it could lead to activating a heavy extension for no real purpose.

I'm not sure if there is prior art for this sort of functionality in package.json, but something like this would be nice:

```
"activationEvents": [
  "if(dart.previewAnalyzeAngularTemplates):onLanguage:html",
  "onLanguage:dart"
]
```

data.title: Test: Windows terminal session renaming
data.body:
Covers https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/30152

- [x] Windows @mjbvz 
- [x] Windows @chrmarti

Complexity 4
### Use [ProcessExplorer](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sysinternals/downloads/process-explorer) to track process trees.
- Verify that the title changes as the process changes and that the title makes sense. eg: `cmd -> cmd, powershell -> powershell, npm -> node, git log -> git, etc`.
- Verify that the title only changes to the first child process (if one exists) of the shell unless the child is one of `[bash, cmd, powershell]` where we'd check that child's children etc. eg: `Initial shell = cmd`. Git log will spawn a child process called less `cmd -> git -> less`. The title will show git and not less since git is the first child of cmd. If the tree is  `cmd -> powershell -> bash -> cmd -> powershell` then the title would be powershell since all those processes are shells.
- Verify that the terminal title is not overriden after the user or an API sets it.
- It is known that creating an external process (eg: `start <shell>`) will have the title stuck as conhost until that process is closed.

data.title: launch.json configuration generated command can't be parsed by external program because multi-word argument has single quotes around it
data.body:
In debug configurations (launch.json), when arguments are multi-word such as "--config someArg someVal", they are parsed into '--config someArg someVal' and appended to the final run command (including single-quotes). Is there a way to prevent this behaviour and keep them as they are?

After running the config below I get the following command:
`'C:\Program Files\nodejs\node.exe' --debug-brk=32795 --nolazy node_modules\jasmine-node\lib\jasmine-node\cli.js --color --verbose --captureExceptions '--config someArg someVal' someDir`

jasmine-node does not recognize its format and displays the help text, so the debug output is:

```
USAGE: jasmine-node [--color|--noColor] [--verbose] [--coffee] directory
Options:
...
--config NAME VALUE- set a global variable in process.env
...
```

If I remove the --config arg the debug session starts (and an exception is thrown since the env arg is missing).

Now, if I remove the single quotes around '--config someVar someVal' and then run the command in a terminal, the program runs.

It seems jasmine is unable to parse the argument when it's around single quotes, and I can't use the VSCode debugger. Any help would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks!

- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.2 (cb82febafda0c8c199b9201ad274e25d9a76874e, 2017-07-19T23:34:09.706Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601
- Extensions:

---|---|---

2. create debug configuration:

            "--captureExceptions",

data.title: Allow search by snippet name in Insert Snippet menu
data.body:
After installing a snippet pack, it's common for me to think: "I know I have a snippet for this, but I don't know the prefix." To find the prefix, I have to either `Insert Snippet` and scroll until I find it, or open the documentation for the relevant snippet pack.

My proposed solution is to make text typed in the `Insert Snippet` menu match both Snippet prefixes and descriptions. For example, to find "Add event listener," I could type `add` rather than having to guess that its prefix is `ae`:

![snippet-search](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/224895/28787960-5d3443f8-75ec-11e7-8cab-1ee6987a2df5.gif)

data.title: Error: Cannot find module 'vscode' when use vscode in server
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version:1.14.2
- OS Version:win10 X64

Steps to Reproduce:

1.clone the official example for language server from https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-languageserver-node-example
2.then follow these steps:
> cd client
> npm install
> code .
> cd ../server
> npm install
append "post install": "node ./node_modules/vscode/bin/install" to scripts in package.json
> npm install vscode -save
> code .
3. open server.ts which located in server/src folder, then add a line import * as vscode from 'vscode' at the beginning  of server.ts.
4. press ctrl+shift+B to build task.
5. after build finished press f5 under client folder
6. error message is shown below:
Error: Cannot find module 'vscode'
    at Function.Module._resolveFilename (module.js:470:15)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:418:25)
    at Module.require (module.js:498:17)
    at require (internal/module.js:20:19)
    at Object.<anonymous> 


<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: Dragging tabs and new window behaviour
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.2 (cb82febafda0c8c199b9201ad274e25d9a76874e, 2017-07-19T23:34:09.706Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: none
---

So I come from using sublime for years, so far I am enjoying VS Code, but there are a few usability things I'd like to raise. Can we change the behaviour when dragging a file tab out of the VSCode window that it automatically creates a new window and opens the file in there, and removes the tab from the original window? This is the behaviour in sublime, and it is very nice to be able to just drag a tab out to another monitor and continue coding.

Another thing which is similar, if you already have another window of VSCode open, and you drag a tab over to the other window it creates two instances of the open file, which is a problem because you can lose track which one you were using if you have many files/windows/tabs open. Changing the behaviour that dragging a tab over to another window closes the original tab reduces confusion. 

Can we make this default? If not, how would I go about changing it myself?

data.body: Export all the settings including themes, plugins etc. And while import settings, vscode automatically download all required themes and plugins etc.
